question.text: A mother is afflicted by Down's syndrome caused by an extra copy of chromosome 21. The father is normal. Thus, the percentage of offspring affected by the disorder would be

solution.text: Down's Syndrome is case of trisomy of  <math><msup><mrow><mn>21</mn></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi></mrow></msup></math>  chromosome. In which  <math><msup><mrow><mn>21</mn></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi></mrow></msup></math>  pair carries 3 chromosomes. During gamete formation 50% gametes carry normal number of chromosomes i.e. 23, but remaining 50% gametes carry 24 chromosomes (one more chromosome in  <math><msup><mrow><mn>21</mn></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi></mrow></msup></math>  pair). So if gamete with 24 chromosomes is fused with male gemete (sperm) then again case of Down's syndrome is generated.
